snippet.title: How conflict minerals funded a war that killed millions, and why tech giants are finally cleaning up their act
snippet.description: The rich mineral mines of the Democratic Republic of Congo supply valuable minerals to the tech industry, but they come at a deadly cost that is finally being faced.

snippet.title: First came the artists, then came the hackers: The strange history of London's own Silicon Valley
snippet.description: London is creating a wave of new tech startups that are finding inspiration in regenerating a crumbling Dickensian district of the historic city.

snippet.title: The rise of Tizen: A new competitor in the mobile market segment
snippet.description: Tizen, the mobile OS developed by Samsung and the Linux Foundation, appears to be heading towards an initial device offering for consumers.

snippet.title: Four steps to making the most of your unstructured data gold mine
snippet.description: Mine the value from your unstructured data by following these steps. You'll also learn how to cut the time it takes your business to answer strategic questions based on that data.

snippet.title: Five mostly free apps for compressing archive files in Windows
snippet.description: There are some application gems out there for handling archives in Windows with great power and flexibility.

snippet.title: Tips on choosing a cloud backup provider for your SMB
snippet.description: These are seven factors your small or medium business should consider when selecting a cloud backup provider.

snippet.title: Getting the most from 4G and wireline networks
snippet.description: How does 4G wireless fit into your total network plan? Here are the scenarios in which it excels, and a few places where IT needs to improve performance.

snippet.title: Five cloud-based CRM apps
snippet.description: A closer look at five relatively-inexpensive cloud-based CRM apps aimed at small businesses expecting to grow.

snippet.title: How app developers can get their pots of gold
snippet.description: There are more ways than ever to create and consume content. This is good news for software developers, who now have even more opportunities to strike it rich.

snippet.title: Review: PrintMaster 2012 Platinum
snippet.description: If you like to get creative with making posters, greeting cards, and banners, PrintMaster is a sound product that doesn't cost a fortune.
